pullRequest.body:
Recall that when `C` is both a category and a `V`-enriched category, we say it is an `EnrichedOrdinaryCategory` if it comes equipped with an equivalence between morphisms `X ‚ü∂ Y` in `C`  and morphisms `ùüô_ V ‚ü∂ (X ‚ü∂[V] Y)` in `V` that preserves identities and composition in `C`.

In such a `V`-enriched ordinary category `C`, isomorphisms in `C` induce isomorphisms between hom-objects in `V`. We define this isomorphism, `CategoryTheory.Iso.eHomCongr`, and prove that it behaves nicely with respect to composition in `C`.

The lemmas here parallel those for unenriched categories in [`Mathlib/CategoryTheory/HomCongr.lean`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/a1c80a59b69da977f8519230ef96b3b95e31bc1d/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/HomCongr.lean) and those for sorts in [`Mathlib/Logic/Equiv/Defs.lean`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/a1c80a59b69da977f8519230ef96b3b95e31bc1d/Mathlib/Logic/Equiv/Defs.lean#L428) (cf. `Equiv.arrowCongr`). Note, however, that they construct equivalences between `Type`s and `Sort`s, respectively, while in this PR we construct isomorphisms between objects in `V`.

---

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ eComp_eHomWhiskerRight`
`+ eHomCongr`
`+ eHomCongr_comp`
`+ eHomCongr_inv_comp`
`+ eHomCongr_refl`
`+ eHomCongr_symm`
`+ eHomCongr_trans`
`+ eHom_whisker_cancel`
`+ eHom_whisker_cancel_inv`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by dagurtomas.

```suggestion
  hom_inv_id := by
    rw [‚Üê eHom_whisker_exchange]
    slice_lhs 2 3 => rw [‚Üê eHomWhiskerRight_comp]
    simp [‚Üê eHomWhiskerLeft_comp]
  inv_hom_id := by
    rw [‚Üê eHom_whisker_exchange]
    slice_lhs 2 3 => rw [‚Üê eHomWhiskerRight_comp]
    simp [‚Üê eHomWhiskerLeft_comp]

```
There is nothing wrong with your proofs, this is just a suggestion that shows how you can let `simp` handle the trivial stuff like `id_comp`, `assoc`, `hom_inv_id`, etc.

```suggestion
@[simps]
def eHomCongr {X Y X‚ÇÅ Y‚ÇÅ : C} (Œ± : X ‚âÖ X‚ÇÅ) (Œ≤ : Y ‚âÖ Y‚ÇÅ) :
```

This is probably what you meant, to generate the lemmas `eHomCongr_hom`, etc.
I don't know if the style guide says anything about this, but I think the ususal practice is to put all these rewrites in a single block.

I was curious about this, actually. I like being able to split up logical steps of the proof within a long string of rewrites, but I also see the aesthetic advantage of combining them. I wasn't able to find anything in the style guide about it, but I do think your suggestion is more in line with what I've seen in mathlib. Thanks.
Note that you can follow the logical steps of a proof by moving your cursor within a big rewrite block (you see how the infoview changes after each lemma)

Is there a reason you prefer `dsimp` to `unfold`? 

In Coq I believe `unfold` would be the "weakest" version of "replace this thing with it's definition", but it seems that is not the case in lean. As I understand it, `unfold` in lean is just `simp` with some special settings, but I haven't been able to figure out what those settings are.

I don't think there is much difference between `unfold foo` and `dsimp [foo]`, the suggestion was just to conform with the style of the surrounding proofs. I also think the `dsimp` version is more common in mathlib, but that's just a feeling.

pullRequest.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Enriched): Add eHomCongr and related lemmas
